title: MEL: Metadata Extractor & Loader

sentences.text: The metadata and content-based information extraction tasks from heterogeneous file sets are pre-processing steps of many Knowledge Graph Construction Pipelines (KGCP).
These tasks often take longer than necessary due to the lack of proper tools that integrate several complementary extraction methods and properties to get a rich output set.

This paper presents MEL, a Python-based tool that implements a set of methods to extract metadata and content-based information from unstructured information encoded in different source document formats.
The results are generated as JSON files, which can: (a) optionally be stored in a document store, and (b) easily be mapped to RDF using a variety of tools such as J2RM.
MEL supports more than 20 different file types, making it a versatile tool that aids pre-processing tasks as part of a KGCP based on comprehensive configurable settings.
This paper introduces MEL, a tool that implements a set of methods to extract metadata and content-based information from various file formats as JSON objects.
For each supported file type, MEL extracts the textual content from the source document and performs specific pre-processing and data cleaning tasks.
Also, it performs basic text analysis tasks (pattern matching and keyword extraction) and generates the results in a machine-readable format (JSON), preparing the ground for content-based analysis.

MEL is integrated with “The NLP -NER Toolkit” (TNNT), which automates the extraction task of categorised named entities from the MEL results by using diverse state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models [5].

MEL implements primitives for metadata and content extraction from unstructured data sets of heterogeneous formats, and along with the TNNT results, it provides the groundwork for content-based analysis.
MEL and TNNT were developed in conjunction with J2RM [4], to easily map the JSON results to RDF as part of an automated KGCP.
MEL has comprehensive metadata extraction support of various file types and formats.

In a nutshell: (1) it takes as input a document (file) set; (2) then, for each document, it extracts its related metadata and content-based information, while performing basic text analysis (such as applying a configurable set of regular expressions and keyword extraction task); and, (3) as output, it generates a JSON file with the extracted metadata and text content with a structure based on the supported formats' document object model.
It can store the results in a document store.
MEL's general output structure is presented in Table 1.

MEL has a detailed configuration JSON file that defines how the processing will be performed through a set of parameters and flags that establish the initial settings related to the document store, input document sets, TNNT general configuration, file extension mappings, the “Associated-Metadata” processing (Table 1), and regular expressions to apply in the text analysis task, among other settings.
The supported file types are presented in Table 2.

The third column shows the theoretical number of attributes that the tool is able to extract per document type, whilst the fourth column shows the average of the extracted attributes from four use case document sets.
OLE 2 file types and .docm can only be processed on Windows operating systems.
Specifically for OLE 2 file types, MEL uses the olemeta tool.
MEL is fully integrated with TNNT as depicted in Figure 1.
The set of Python-based methods implemented in MEL are generic and can be applied to extract the content and metadata of all supported file types.
MEL uses various opensource packages and tools with complementary capabilities to form a “Swiss army knife” of metadata and content-based information extraction from heterogeneous document sets.

As part of the “General-Metadata” extraction task, MEL optionally uses the XML output from the NLNZ Metadata Extractor tool, a Java standalone tool that extracts a comprehensive attribute and property list from dozens of file formats.
The MEL general processing model is presented in Figure 2.
It is important to note that each file type has its own specific processing model as well as the text analysis task, which is the last step that is performed for any output.
The most comprehensive and current state-of-the-art tool for content extraction and analysis is Apache Tika, which is a complete and complex Java-based general-purpose system.

While MEL's core goals resemble the ones of Apache Tika, the main difference and benefit of MEL as compared to Apache Tika is that it is a lightweight Python-based package for the metadata extraction of common file formats aimed to be used in a KGCP.

Although there is a wide range of Python-based tools and libraries for metadata extraction, to the best of our knowledge, there is no package available that fully integrates in one system a comprehensive set of methods for metadata and content extraction of common file formats that generate the results in JSON structures based on the document object model of each format type.
Last, MEL can assist in the information extraction stage of several KGCPs, such as the ones described in [6], [2], and [3].
MEL provides a versatile mechanism to extract metadata and content-based information from unstructured data sets of heterogeneous file formats, agnostic of the data sets' domain (general purpose).
It has been tested over thousands of documents using different formats and datasets as part of the AGRIF project.
Based on the structure of the MEL's JSON results, it is possible to easily add a vocabulary or light-weight ontology using JSON-LD annotations, in order to make the extracted metadata “RDF ready”.
This will be explored in the near future leveraging on the integration with JSON-LD ontologies.
More file formats will be added in a per use-case requirements basis, in order to support KGCP tasks.
Additionally, a project to “containerise” the MEL+TNNT tools is planned in the near future.

The major contributions of this tool are: (1) the ability to extract metadata sets and content-based information from different source document formats; (2) the comprehensive support of over 20 different file types/formats integrated into one easy-to-use Python-based system; (3) integration with TNNT which automates the extraction of categorised named entities from the results by using diverse state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models; and (4) the JSON result files can be easily mapped to RDF using J2RM.

Entity-mel_s_core_goal.label: MEL's core goals
Entity-mel_s_core_goal.description: The core objectives or purposes of MEL, which define its primary motivations and directions.

Entity-json_object.label: JSON objects
Entity-json_object.description: A type of data structure used for exchanging structured data between web servers, applications, and other systems.

Entity-opensource_package_and_tool_with_.label: opensource packages and tools with complementary capabilities
aliases: opensource packages and tools with complementary capabilities
Entity-opensource_package_and_tool_with_.description: A collection of open-source software packages and tools that offer complementary capabilities

mentions.local_name: opensource packages and tools with complementary capabilities

Entity-regular_expression.label: regular expressions
aliases: regular expressions to apply in the text analysis task
Entity-regular_expression.description: A set of patterns used for string matching and searching, allowing for the definition of complex search criteria using syntax-specific rules.

mentions.local_name: regular expressions to apply in the text analysis task

Entity-json-ld.label: JSON-LD
Entity-json-ld.description: A semantic extension to JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) for expressing structured data and schema information.

Entity-processing_model.label: processing model
Entity-processing_model.description: A conceptual framework or set of rules governing how data is transformed and analyzed to produce a desired outcome.

Entity-unstructured_information.label: unstructured information
aliases: unstructured information encoded in different source document formats
Entity-unstructured_information.description: Information that lacks organization or structure, often requiring manual processing or analysis.

mentions.local_name: unstructured information encoded in different source document formats

Entity-unstructured_data_set.label: unstructured data sets
aliases: unstructured data sets of heterogeneous formats
Entity-unstructured_data_set.description: A collection of data that lacks a predefined structure or organization.

mentions.local_name: unstructured data sets of heterogeneous formats

Entity-python-based_tool.label: Python-based tool
Entity-python-based_tool.description: A software development platform or framework written in Python, used for programming.

Entity-python-based_method.label: Python-based methods
Entity-python-based_method.description: Programming techniques or algorithms that utilize the programming language Python.

Entity-proper_tool.label: proper tools
Entity-proper_tool.description: Specialized equipment or software designed for specific purposes, providing efficient and effective means of accomplishing tasks.

Entity-file_extension_mapping.label: file extension mappings
Entity-file_extension_mapping.description: A table or database that maps file extensions to their corresponding formats

Entity-file_type_are_presented_in_table_.label: file types are presented in Table 2
aliases: file types are presented in Table 2
Entity-file_type_are_presented_in_table_.description: A list of file formats or extensions that can be processed, stored, or used by a system or application.

mentions.local_name: file types are presented in Table 2

Entity-document_store.label: document store
Entity-document_store.description: A digital repository for storing and managing documents.

Entity-pre-processing_task.label: pre-processing tasks
aliases: specific pre-processing and data cleaning tasks
Entity-pre-processing_task.description: A set of operations performed to prepare data for further processing or analysis.

mentions.local_name: specific pre-processing and data cleaning tasks

Entity-document_type.label: document type
Entity-document_type.description: A classification or categorization scheme used to classify and organize documents based on their characteristics, structure, or content.

Entity-table_1.label: Table 1
Entity-table_1.description: A table presenting reference information or data.

Entity-method.label: methods
Entity-method.description: A collection of algorithms or processes used for achieving a specific goal

Entity-ole.label: OLE
Entity-ole.description: A proprietary file format or data structure

Entity-named_entity.label: named entities
Entity-named_entity.description: A collection or set of identified concepts, things, or ideas

Entity-third_column.label: third column
Entity-third_column.description: A vertical division or section in a structured data arrangement, typically used to organize and display information.

Entity-ontology.label: ontologies
Entity-ontology.description: A set of formal representations that define a common understanding of concepts and relationships, used to reason about knowledge.

Entity-primitive.label: primitives
Entity-primitive.description: Basic building blocks or fundamental operations used to perform a specific task

Entity-theoretical_number_of_attribute.label: theoretical number of attributes
Entity-theoretical_number_of_attribute.description: A numerical value representing an estimated or predicted quantity of characteristics, features, or properties that can be extracted from a given dataset.

Entity-opensource_package_and_tool.label: opensource packages and tools
Entity-opensource_package_and_tool.description: A collection of software libraries, frameworks, or tools that are freely available for use, modification, and distribution under an open-source license.

Entity-.docm_can_only_be_processed_on_wi.label: .docm can only be processed on Windows operating systems
aliases: .docm can only be processed on Windows operating systems
Entity-.docm_can_only_be_processed_on_wi.description: A specific type of Microsoft Office document that requires a Windows operating system to process.

mentions.local_name: .docm can only be processed on Windows operating systems

Entity-vocabulary_or_light-weight_ontolo.label: vocabulary or light-weight ontology
Entity-vocabulary_or_light-weight_ontolo.description: A formal, standardized set of concepts and terms used for knowledge representation and organization.

Entity-project.label: project
Entity-project.description: A research program or initiative aimed at achieving specific goals, objectives, and outcomes.

Entity-window.label: Windows
Entity-window.description: A graphical user interface (GUI) environment developed by Microsoft, used for interacting with a computer.

Entity-parameter_and_flag.label: parameters and flags
Entity-parameter_and_flag.description: A set of configuration options or variables that control the initial setup or parameters for a processing system.

Entity-result.label: results
Entity-result.description: The outcome or product of an operation, process, or experiment.

Entity-task.label: tasks
Entity-task.description: A task or activity, typically requiring effort or time to complete.

Entity-figure_2.label: Figure 2
Entity-figure_2.description: A visual representation, typically an image or diagram.

Entity-the_near_future.label: the near future
Entity-the_near_future.description: The time period immediately ahead, which has not yet arrived but is expected to happen soon.

summary:
The metadata and content-based information extraction tasks from heterogeneous file sets are pre-processing steps of many Knowledge Graph Construction Pipelines (KGCP). These tasks often take longer than necessary due to the lack of proper tools that integrate several complementary extraction methods and properties to get a rich output set. This paper presents MEL, a Python-based tool that implements a set of methods to extract metadata and content-based information from unstructured information encoded in different source document formats. The results are generated as JSON files, which can: (a) optionally be stored in a document store, and (b) easily be mapped to RDF using a variety of tools such as J2RM. MEL supports more than 20 different file types, making it a versatile tool that aids pre-processing tasks as part of a KGCP based on comprehensive configurable settings.

This paper introduces MEL, a tool that implements a set of methods to extract metadata and content-based information from various file formats as JSON objects. For each supported file type, MEL extracts the textual content from the source document and performs specific pre-processing and data cleaning tasks. Also, it performs basic text analysis tasks (pattern matching and keyword extraction) and generates the results in a machine-readable format (JSON), preparing the ground for content-based analysis. MEL is integrated with “The NLP -NER Toolkit” (TNNT), which automates the extraction task of categorised named entities from the MEL results by using diverse state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models [5]. MEL implements primitives for metadata and content extraction from unstructured data sets of heterogeneous formats, and along with the TNNT results, it provides the groundwork for content-based analysis. MEL and TNNT were developed in conjunction with J2RM [4], to easily map the JSON results to RDF as part of an automated KGCP.

MEL has comprehensive metadata extraction support of various file types and formats. In a nutshell: (1) it takes as input a document (file) set; (2) then, for each document, it extracts its related metadata and content-based information, while performing basic text analysis (such as applying a configurable set of regular expressions and keyword extraction task); and, (3) as output, it generates a JSON file with the extracted metadata and text content with a structure based on the supported formats' document object model. It can store the results in a document store. MEL's general output structure is presented in Table 1. MEL has a detailed configuration JSON file that defines how the processing will be performed through a set of parameters and flags that establish the initial settings related to the document store, input document sets, TNNT general configuration, file extension mappings, the “Associated-Metadata” processing (Table 1), and regular expressions to apply in the text analysis task, among other settings. The supported file types are presented in Table 2. The third column shows the theoretical number of attributes that the tool is able to extract per document type, whilst the fourth column shows the average of the extracted attributes from four use case document sets. OLE 2 file types and .docm can only be processed on Windows operating systems. Specifically for OLE 2 file types, MEL uses the olemeta tool.

MEL is fully integrated with TNNT as depicted in Figure 1. The set of Python-based methods implemented in MEL are generic and can be applied to extract the content and metadata of all supported file types. MEL uses various opensource packages and tools with complementary capabilities to form a “Swiss army knife” of metadata and content-based information extraction from heterogeneous document sets. As part of the “General-Metadata” extraction task, MEL optionally uses the XML output from the NLNZ Metadata Extractor tool, a Java standalone tool that extracts a comprehensive attribute and property list from dozens of file formats. The MEL general processing model is presented in Figure 2. It is important to note that each file type has its own specific processing model as well as the text analysis task, which is the last step that is performed for any output.

The most comprehensive and current state-of-the-art tool for content extraction and analysis is Apache Tika, which is a complete and complex Java-based general-purpose system. While MEL's core goals resemble the ones of Apache Tika, the main difference and benefit of MEL as compared to Apache Tika is that it is a lightweight Python-based package for the metadata extraction of common file formats aimed to be used in a KGCP. Although there is a wide range of Python-based tools and libraries for metadata extraction, to the best of our knowledge, there is no package available that fully integrates in one system a comprehensive set of methods for metadata and content extraction of common file formats that generate the results in JSON structures based on the document object model of each format type. Last, MEL can assist in the information extraction stage of several KGCPs, such as the ones described in [6], [2], and [3].

MEL provides a versatile mechanism to extract metadata and content-based information from unstructured data sets of heterogeneous file formats, agnostic of the data sets' domain (general purpose). It has been tested over thousands of documents using different formats and datasets as part of the AGRIF project. Based on the structure of the MEL's JSON results, it is possible to easily add a vocabulary or light-weight ontology using JSON-LD annotations, in order to make the extracted metadata “RDF ready”. This will be explored in the near future leveraging on the integration with JSON-LD ontologies. More file formats will be added in a per use-case requirements basis, in order to support KGCP tasks. Additionally, a project to “containerise” the MEL+TNNT tools is planned in the near future. The major contributions of this tool are: (1) the ability to extract metadata sets and content-based information from different source document formats; (2) the comprehensive support of over 20 different file types/formats integrated into one easy-to-use Python-based system; (3) integration with TNNT which automates the extraction of categorised named entities from the results by using diverse state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models; and (4) the JSON result files can be easily mapped to RDF using J2RM.

Predicate-are_pre-processing_steps_of.label: are pre-processing steps of
Predicate-are_pre-processing_steps_of.description: The predicate 'are pre-processing steps of' indicates a relationship between two entities where the subject entity (content-based information extraction tasks) involves or consists of specific preparatory actions or procedures that lead to the creation or development of the object entity (KGCP). In general, this predicate suggests that the subject's purpose is to prepare for or lay the groundwork for the object.

Predicate-often_take_longer_than_necessa.label: often take longer than necessary due to the lack of
Predicate-often_take_longer_than_necessa.description: This predicate indicates that a subject's action or process (often taking something) is hindered by the absence or insufficiency of an object, resulting in unnecessary prolongation. The lack of the object serves as a constraint, causing the subject to take longer than necessary to complete its task.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates the act of introducing or making available something (the object) through a medium or representation (typically embodied by the subject).

Predicate-be_generated_as.label: be generated as
Predicate-be_generated_as.description: This predicate indicates a transformation or conversion process that yields a specific outcome. It connects the subject to an object by describing how the subject is transformed into, or takes on the characteristics of, the object.

Predicate-can_be_mapped_to.label: can be mapped to
Predicate-can_be_mapped_to.description: Indicates that there exists a transformation or correspondence between two entities (subject and object), allowing for the representation, conversion, or translation of one into another. This predicate suggests an equivalence or similarity relationship between the subject and object, enabling their mapping or matching.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates that the subject has a capacity to accommodate or facilitate the object. In general, it suggests an enabling or facilitating relationship between the subject and the object.

Predicate-introduces.label: introduces
Predicate-introduces.description: Introduces refers to the act of presenting or bringing forth information, concepts, ideas, or entities for consideration, explanation, or understanding. It connects a subject (typically an author, creator, or source) with an object that represents new knowledge, perspectives, or insights.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates a process of obtaining or deriving specific information, features, or components from a given source (subject), resulting in a particular outcome or representation (object).

Predicate-performs.label: performs
Predicate-performs.description: The predicate 'performs' indicates that the subject is engaged in or carries out a specific action or task described by the object. It implies a sense of agency and responsibility, suggesting that the subject has control over the execution of the task.

Predicate-generates.label: generates
Predicate-generates.description: The predicate 'generates' indicates a relationship where the subject produces or creates something new, often in response to an input or stimulus. The object represents the outcome or result of this generation process.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' indicates that the subject (in this case, MEL) provides or uses a specific set of tools, methods, techniques, or systems to achieve a particular goal or function. The object represents the thing being implemented, which can be a process, system, framework, library, protocol, etc.

Predicate-developed_in_conjunction_with.label: developed in conjunction with
Predicate-developed_in_conjunction_with.description: Indicates a collaborative effort or partnership between two entities (subject and object), where the subject has contributed to or been involved in the development of something related to the object, often implying mutual influence or coordination.

Predicate-has_comprehensive_metadata_ext.label: has comprehensive metadata extraction support of various file types and formats
Predicate-has_comprehensive_metadata_ext.description: This predicate indicates that a subject entity possesses or provides capabilities for extracting comprehensive metadata from diverse file types and formats. It highlights the subject's ability to process and analyze various forms of digital content, revealing its underlying structure, properties, and relationships.

Predicate-extracts_its_related_metadata_.label: extracts its related metadata and content-based information
Predicate-extracts_its_related_metadata_.description: This predicate describes an action where a subject (e.g., MEL) retrieves or obtains relevant metadata and content-based information that is related to itself. The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea of gathering, accessing, or processing data that provides context, meaning, or insight about the subject.

Predicate-takes_as_input.label: takes as input
Predicate-takes_as_input.description: Indicates that the subject receives or processes information from the object. This predicate establishes a relationship between the subject and the object where the subject relies on, utilizes, or consumes data provided by the object.

Predicate-can_store.label: can store
Predicate-can_store.description: The predicate 'can store' indicates that the subject has the ability or capacity to retain or hold onto something (the object), often referring to physical or abstract entities, such as objects, data, information, or results.

Predicate-store.label: store
Predicate-store.description: To store means to keep or maintain something in a location for future use or access. The predicate 'store' connects the subject (the entity performing the action of storing) with an object that represents the thing being stored, such as a physical space, digital repository, or abstract concept.

Predicate-stores_the_results_in_a_docume.label: stores the results in a document store
Predicate-stores_the_results_in_a_docume.description: This predicate indicates that the subject entity takes some action or holds onto certain information and saves it within a designated storage system known as a 'document store'. The connection between the subject and object lies in the idea of containment, where the subject's results are physically stored within the document store.

Predicate-is_presented_in.label: is presented in
Predicate-is_presented_in.description: The predicate 'is presented in' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, MEL) has its contents or information displayed within or organized by the object (Table 1). This connection suggests that the subject is being showcased, summarized, or categorized according to some structure or framework provided by the object.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a clear and explicit explanation or specification of the object. This connection implies that the subject has authority, expertise, or control over the definition of the object.

Predicate-generates_a_JSON_file_with_the.label: generates a JSON file with the extracted metadata and text content
Predicate-generates_a_JSON_file_with_the.description: This predicate indicates that the subject entity transforms or produces a JSON file containing both metadata and textual information. The connection between the subject and object lies in the process of creating a structured data representation, where the subject's output (the extracted metadata and text content) takes the form of a JSON file.

Predicate-are_presented_in.label: are presented in
Predicate-are_presented_in.description: The predicate 'are presented in' indicates a relationship where information or data about the subject is displayed or organized within the object. The object typically represents a container, such as a table, figure, or section, that holds and presents the relevant details about the subject.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: The predicate 'shows' indicates a relationship where the subject represents or demonstrates something about the object. This can be interpreted as revealing, displaying, or illustrating information that is inherent to the object.

Predicate-can_only_be_processed_by.label: can only be processed by
Predicate-can_only_be_processed_by.description: This predicate indicates that a specific entity (subject) requires or is compatible with a particular system, software, tool, or agent (object), which has the capability to process or handle it. The connection between the subject and object implies a functional relationship where the object's processing capabilities are necessary for the subject to be utilized, interpreted, or operated upon.

Predicate-uses_for.label: uses for
Predicate-uses_for.description: The predicate 'uses for' indicates a relationship between a subject and an object where the subject has a specific purpose or function related to the object. In general, this predicate suggests that the subject utilizes or employs the object for a particular reason.

Predicate-takes_as_input_a_document_set.label: takes as input a document set
Predicate-takes_as_input_a_document_set.description: This predicate indicates that the subject entity processes or utilizes a collection of documents (a 'document set') to perform some operation. The connection between the subject and object lies in the fact that the subject relies on, consumes, or transforms the document sets provided as input.

Predicate-is_fully_integrated_with.label: is fully integrated with
Predicate-is_fully_integrated_with.description: Indicates a state of unity or cohesion between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that they share resources, capabilities, or goals to achieve a common objective. This predicate implies a high level of coordination, cooperation, and mutual understanding.

Predicate-implemented_in.label: implemented in
Predicate-implemented_in.description: Indicates that a specific implementation or realization exists for something (the subject), which is carried out using a particular method, framework, language, etc. (the object).

Predicate-optionally_uses.label: optionally uses
Predicate-optionally_uses.description: The predicate 'optionally uses' indicates that the subject has a possibility or choice to employ the object as part of its functioning, process, or operation. This relationship suggests that the subject may utilize the object under certain circumstances, but it does not necessarily rely on the object for its core functionality.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or association between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the properties or attributes described in the object.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates a statement of identity or equivalence between the subject and object, suggesting that they share a common characteristic, property, or quality. It implies a sense of correspondence or similarity between the two entities.

Predicate-be.label: be
Predicate-be.description: The predicate 'be' connects the subject to an attribute or characteristic that defines its nature, essence, or identity. It establishes a state of being between the subject and object, indicating that the subject possesses or embodies the quality described by the object.

Predicate-has_been_tested_over.label: has been tested over
Predicate-has_been_tested_over.description: The predicate 'has been tested over' indicates a relationship where the subject (a system or entity) has undergone testing or evaluation on a specific domain, scope, or range of things denoted by the object. This connection suggests that the subject's capabilities, performance, or quality have been assessed and validated within this particular context.

Predicate-will_be_explored_in.label: will be explored in
Predicate-will_be_explored_in.description: The predicate 'will be explored in' indicates a planned or intended investigation into something. It suggests that the subject (a person, entity, etc.) will engage with and examine the object (an idea, concept, topic, etc.) at some point in time.

Predicate-will_be_added_in_a_per_use-cau.label: will be added in a per use-cause requirements basis to support
Predicate-will_be_added_in_a_per_use-cau.description: This predicate indicates that additional information or resources are being provided on an as-needed basis to facilitate understanding or utilization of the subject. The object represents the type of support or resource being added, which may vary depending on specific use cases and requirements.

Predicate-integrate_with.label: integrate with
Predicate-integrate_with.description: To combine or unify two entities (subject and object) into a cohesive whole, often to facilitate communication, processing, or analysis. This predicate indicates that the subject entity has been brought together with another entity to form a new relationship, share information, or achieve a common goal.

Predicate-map_to.label: map to
Predicate-map_to.description: The predicate 'map to' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, JSON files) corresponds or relates to the object (J2RM [4]), often implying an equivalence, conversion, or representation of one concept by another.

Predicate-can_assist.label: can assist
Predicate-can_assist.description: The predicate 'can assist' indicates that the subject has the capability or ability to offer support, guidance, or aid in achieving a specific goal or task. It implies a potential for collaboration and cooperation between the subject and other entities involved.

Predicate-can_extract.label: <can_extract>
Predicate-can_extract.description: Indicates that a subject has the capability or ability to perform an action on an object, such as extracting information from it.

Predicate-implement.label: implement
Predicate-implement.description: To implement means to put into effect or bring into practice a plan, method, system, or concept. It implies taking an idea or design and making it operational, often by creating the necessary structures, processes, or tools.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to_extract.label: can be applied to extract
Predicate-can_be_applied_to_extract.description: This predicate indicates that a subject has the capability or potential to apply an extraction process to obtain information from an object. It implies that the subject can operate on the object in some way, extracting relevant data or content.

Predicate-6.description: The predicate '6' represents a reference or citation to external sources of information. It indicates that the subject has some connection or relevance to the cited works, which are typically academic papers or publications.

Predicate-assists.label: assists
Predicate-assists.description: The predicate 'assists' indicates that the subject provides support or aid to achieve a specific goal, outcome, or process described in the object. It implies a helping relationship between the subject and the context specified by the object.

Predicate-assists_in.label: <assists_in>
Predicate-assists_in.description: <assists_in> indicates that the subject provides support or facilitation for the object to achieve a specific goal, task, or process.

Predicate-is_part_of.label: is part of
Predicate-is_part_of.description: The predicate 'is part of' indicates a relationship where the subject is an integral component or element within the object, suggesting that the subject plays a significant role or has a defined position within the larger structure or system represented by the object.

Predicate-supports_(1).label: supports
Predicate-supports_(1).description: The predicate 'supports' indicates the provision or availability of resources, tools, or functionality to facilitate or enable something. It suggests that the subject has the capacity to aid, assist, or make possible the existence or operation of the object.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates the process of creating or refining something, often implying a sense of growth, improvement, or maturation. It connects the subject to an object that has undergone or will undergo development, highlighting the transformation from one state to another.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates that the subject entity employs or utilizes the object to achieve a specific purpose or function.

Predicate-consists_of.label: consists_of
Predicate-consists_of.description: The predicate 'consists_of' indicates that the subject is composed or made up of one or more entities, concepts, or components described by the object. It implies a relationship of containment, membership, or composition between the subject and the object.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to.label: can be applied to
Predicate-can_be_applied_to.description: The predicate 'can be applied to' indicates the relationship between an entity (subject) that has a specific capability or function, and another entity (object) that can benefit from or utilize this capability. In general, it suggests that the subject's capabilities are relevant or applicable to the object.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject offers or makes available something to someone, typically denoting a service, resource, or tool that satisfies a need or requirement. In this context, it suggests that the subject provides access to or furnishes the object as a means of achieving a specific goal or solving a particular problem.

Predicate-is_extracted_by.label: is extracted by
Predicate-is_extracted_by.description: Indicates that a subject entity has its information or content processed and obtained from an object entity. The predicate 'is extracted by' suggests a relationship of extraction, where the subject is the source material being analyzed, and the object is the tool, method, or system responsible for extracting relevant information.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject has a relationship of inclusion or possession towards the object. It suggests that the subject holds or encompasses the object within itself, either physically or abstractly.

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: To create or produce something new from existing information or resources. This predicate indicates that the subject takes action to bring forth a new entity, concept, or output that did not previously exist.

Predicate-is_output_of.label: is_output_of
Predicate-is_output_of.description: The predicate 'is_output_of' indicates a relationship between an entity (subject) and its resulting product or outcome (object), where the subject is responsible for generating, producing, or processing something that yields the object.

Predicate-is_generated_by.label: is generated by
Predicate-is_generated_by.description: The predicate 'is generated by' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has been created or produced as a result of some process or mechanism. The object represents the underlying force, system, or entity responsible for generating the subject.

Predicate-is_implemented_by.label: is implemented by
Predicate-is_implemented_by.description: The predicate 'is implemented by' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) has its functionality or process carried out, managed, or executed by another entity (the object). This connection implies that the object is responsible for performing or realizing the actions described by the subject.

Predicate-MEL_implements.label: MEL implements
Predicate-MEL_implements.description: The predicate 'MEL implements' indicates that a specific entity (the subject) provides or offers an implementation for something else (the object). This relationship suggests that the subject has developed, created, or integrated a particular solution, framework, or system to achieve a certain goal or fulfill a need.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or classified under the object. It suggests a hierarchical relationship where the subject is a specific instance of the more general concept represented by the object.
